metadata.title: Stroke Rehabilitation  Therapeutic Exercise
synonyms: cerebral vascular accident (cv a) rehabilitation  therapeutic exercise
description: Stroke is a nontraumatic brain injury caused by occlusion or rupture of cerebral blood vessels that results in sudden neurological deficit characterized by loss of motor control, altered sensation, cognitive and/or language impairment, disequilibrium, and/or coma(1,24,32)
Stroke rehabilitation involves various therapeutic interventions aimed at improving functioning and independence after stroke(24)

Literature suggests that many patients who have strokes have premorbid low physical fitness and become significantly more deconditioned after the insult, and that these patients are not being challenged enough in therapy to induce the metabolic stress needed to enhance their cardiopulmonary fitness(2)

Also of importance, neurologically impaired patients require a greater volume of oxygen (VO 2) than healthy controls for ADL performance and ambulation and they rate poor energy levels ahead of mobility limitations, pain, emotional reactions, sleep disturbances, and social isolation as the area of greatest personal concern(2)

Paresis reduces the number of motor units available for recruitment, thereby reducing metabolically active tissue and lowering the oxidative potential. A strong relationship exists between bilateral thigh muscle mass and VO2 peak, but post stroke, it is estimated that 50% of normal motor units are functioning.  (2)

Altered muscle fiber composition and recruitment patterns of paretic muscles may also contribute to poor fitness; elevated proportions of fast, more fatigable fibers that are less glucose sensitive are found in the paretic leg of persons after stroke, contributing to reductions in VO 2 peak(2)

Impairments after stroke can also reduce ventilatory reserve (defined as the difference between the maximal available ventilation and the ventilation measured at the end of exercise), leading to limited oxygen available for exercise(2)
Even small (8–15%)  increases in exercise capacity may be of practical significance for persons with neurological disorders and make the difference between being dependent and being independent(2)
Low fitness levels are associated with higher mortality in the neurologically impaired population(2)

indications: Indicated for patients status post stroke presenting with sensory and motor impairments, decreased cardiovascular conditioning, decreased ability to perform functional mobility and ADLs, decreased balance, and decreased ability to ambulate and negotiate stairs/uneven surfaces (e.g., ramps and curbs)
reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition Indications for Therapeutic Exercise in Stroke Rehabilitation
contraindications precautions to test: Respect the patient’s pain and fatigue
Use caution giving the patient liquids as he or she may have swallowing precautions
These patients are at high risk for falls; provide appropriate assistance during examination

These patients are at high risk for communication issues secondary to aphasia and cognitive issues. Be aware that the patient may have difficulty understanding instructions or communicating pain and other sensations/needs; care should be taken to ensure safety and that the patient’s needs are met
Do not assist or support through the hemiplegic arm

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Date of stroke -Type and location of stroke -Initial presenting symptoms and how soon the patient received medical intervention after onset of symptoms -Comorbidities/complications (e.g., DVT, pneumonia, shoulder pain) -History of hospitalization since onset of stroke (e.g., Was the patient in the ICU? How long was he or she hospitalized?) -Progression of recovery up to this point(e.g., has the patient recovered any strength if he or she presented with flaccidity initially? Is any abnormal tone resolving or developing?) -Is speech or swallowing affected?

course of treatment.medical management: Of what did the patient’s initial medical management consist? Potential interventions(1,24,32) Mechanical ventilation with intubation Oxygen Tube feeding Bladder dysfunction—catheterization Intracranial pressure monitoring BP monitoring, ECG Frequent monitoring and control of serum glucose levels Surgical interventions Placement of external ventriculostomy device for acute cerebral edema and hydrocephalus Decompression of the posterior fossa for brainstem compression and hydrocephalus
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? BP medications(1) Antiplatelet agents for atrial fibrillation(1) Statin therapy for elevated cholesterol(1) Antispasticity medications Botulinum toxin is the recommended treatment for focal spastic dystonia(1,24,33) Intrathecal baclofen delivered by implanted infusion pump is recommended for generalized spasticity(1) Oral anti-spasticity  medications such as baclofen, dantrolene, and tizanidine tend to have marginal effects on generalized spasticity and also have side effects that include lethargy and tiredness(33) Pain medications(1,32,33)medications include Amitriptyline and other tricyclic antidepressants Carbamazepine Intravenous ketamine Gabapentin Bowel and bladder Alpha blockers to help complete voiding  Laxatives for bowel evacuation Anticholinergics(32) Medications for depression SSRIs(1,24,32)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Noninvasive option for examining cerebral vessels
Used if there is suspicion of cardioembolic source
Physician-monitored  exercise stress test with continuous ECG and periodic BP monitoring(2)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture), whether they help, and, if they do, with what specifically they help (e.g., pain, spasticity)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Inquire about current course of therapy for acute stroke and past therapy for chronic stroke. Did the patient receive therapy in the hospital? Did the patient go to an acute or subacute rehabilitation facility? Did the patient receive home care or outpatient services? Has the patient previously participated in cardiac rehabilitation?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Inquire about any factors that affect fatigue, pain, mental status, spasticity, or any other variable that may affect the patient’s ability to participate in therapy
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Does the patient report any shortness of breath (SOB), chest pains, palpitations, or leg cramping? How long before onset of symptoms, and how long do symptoms persist before they resolve?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much) -For pain, a nonverbal scale such as the FLACC scale may be used (a V AS or numeric scale may also be used for nonverbal patients such as those with expressive aphasia) -Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale for perceived exertion(2) -Researchers in China found that HR is a better index than RPE in evaluating exercise intensity in stroke patients(19) -In a study involving 32 stroke patients, there was a moderate correlation between HR and oxygen consumption, but a weak correlation between RPE and oxygen consumption
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (AM, mid-day, PM, night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables. Most patients with neurological involvement report a decline in energy levels in the afternoon(2)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, insomnia, sleep-disordered  breathing. Inquire about daytime symptoms that could indicate sleep disturbance such as excessive sleepiness, headaches, fatigue, or irritability
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, headaches, radicular pain, mood disturbances, confusion)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient require the use of supplemental oxygen? Did the patient ever require mechanical ventilation or intubation? History of COPD or other pulmonary disease? History of smoking? Any chronic cough or wheeze? Any activity limitations due to respiratory compromise? Psychosocial status -Stroke survivors are at increased risk for depression; increased exercise capacity has been shown to improve mental well-being(33) -The Beck Depression Index, a self-reported rating inventory, or the Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression can be used(33)  Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__/No__ -If Yes, describe

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Was the patient deconditioned prior to the stroke? Did the patient have weakness or other impairments prior to the stroke? History of prior stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA)?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, pulmonary disease, metabolic disorders, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs) Specifically inquire about any medications that may affect the patient’s cardiovascular or pulmonary system or his or her ability to fully participate in exercise (e.g., beta blockers)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Was the patient working or attending school prior to the stroke? To what recreational or occupational activities does the patient expect to return? Is the patient a smoker? How much daily physical activity does the patient typically do?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Did the patient have any prior functional limitations? Did he or she use any adaptive equipment at work or at home?
social and occupational history.living environment: Does the patient have stairs to negotiate? Number of floors in home? On what floor(s) are the bathroom and bedroom? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; are any modifications necessary? Has the home been assessed for safety? With whom does the patient live? Who are the caregivers? Are they supportive and able to provide necessary care and assistance? -Researchers in South Africa found that patients post stroke rely on caregivers to help them with home exercise programs. The most common barriers to adherence to home exercise programs were identified as general health issues, caregiver having other responsibilities, lack of family and social support, caregiver burden and stress, low self-efficacy and mood, and fear of falling. Common enablers of adherence included caregiver knowledge and attitudes and having a daily routine(36)

relevant tests and measures.general: ›Relevant tests and measures  (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess appropriateness and proper use and fit of any current devices. Assess the need for any other devices, including equipment that assists with bathing, toileting, performing ADLs, performing self-care, ambulation/locomotion, functional mobility and transfers, and pressure relief (mattresses and cushions)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess balance in sit and stance, statically and dynamically, and with perturbations. Assess protective balance reactions and appropriate use of balance strategies. The Berg Balance Scale (BBS),(33)the functional reach test,(3) the Short Form Postural Assessment Scale for Stroke (SF-PASS),(33)and the four square step test (FSST)(3) can be used for objective measurement. The Activities-specific  Balance Confidence (ABC) Scale(3,33) and the Falls Efficacy Scale(33)can be used for subjective assessment. For higher-level  patients, can assess tandem stance, single-limb  stance, and add such variables as eyes closed, head turns, or a compliant surface
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulses bilaterally; note any discrepancies or abnormalitiesAssess for integrity of cranial nerves as indicated and appropriateObserve body mechanics during functional activities; note any faulty mechanics that might be contributing to decreased endurance or faulty mechanics during exerciseAssess all functional mobility and transfers. The FIM and the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test can be used(33)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Perform a thorough gait assessment to detect any abnormalities and to assess safety, utilizing an assistive device as needed. Assess the need for orthotic devices such as an ankle foot orthosis (AFO) or knee ankle foot orthosis (KAFO). Assess for faulty gait mechanics that may increase energy expenditure and contribute to decreased endurance. Assess locomotion with wheelchair if the patient is nonambulatory. Objective measures such as Functional Ambulation Category (FAC),(33)10-meter  walk test (10MWT),(33)Dynamic Gait Index (DGI), and community walking test can be used(3)Assess joint integrity and mobility, especially if the patient has shoulder pain. Assess for shoulder subluxation. Assess for contracturesPerform full motor control assessment. Assess for abnormal tone, –Modified Ashworth Scale (MAS) for spasticity(3) –Fugl-Meyer  Assessment of Motor Recovery(3) –Chedoke-McMaster  Stroke Assessment(2) –Action Research Arm Test (ARAT)(33) –Purdue Peg Board Test/9-hole  peg test(33) –Box and blocks test(33) –Jebsen-Taylor  Hand Function Test(3)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manual muscle testing (MMT) may be used to assess strength in the absence of abnormal tone, synergy patterns, or impaired coordination; can also use handheld dynamometer, pinch meters, and/or isometric testing. Functional strength testing, such as 5 times sit to stand test (5TSTST) or 10-stair  climb test, should be used in the presence of these motor control impairments(3)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess overall posture and posture in wheelchair seating system, if applicable
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess passive ROM (PROM) and flexibility throughout. Document presence of pain with any movements
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess deep tendon reflexes as indicatedAssess ability to perform ADLs and self-care.  The Barthel Index can be used.(33)Refer to occupational therapist (OT) as appropriate
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess for sensory impairment, including light touch, pinprick, temperature, vibration, and pressure
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –SF-36(3) –Stroke Impact Scale(3) –NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assess the patient’s orientation and arousal. Obtain results of testing performed by other disciplines, such as speech therapy and cognitive psychology. Assess the patient’s judgment and safety awareness

other: Patients with stroke may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that the patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
Patients with sensory and neglect issues may not be aware that a part of their body is at risk for injury (e.g., hand getting caught in the wheelchair)
Refer to Contraindications/Precautions to Stroke Rehabilitation Therapeutic Exercise and Contraindications/Precautions to Examination, listed above

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: To increase strength, motor control, and cardiovascular endurance, leading to improvements in functional mobility and ADL performance, balance, and ability to ambulate and negotiate stairs
prognosis: Factors that influence the outcomes of a patient involved in stroke rehabilitation –Type, distribution, pattern, and severity of physical impairment –Cognitive, language, communication, and learning ability –Number, types, and severity of comorbid medical conditions –Coping ability and style –Nature and amount of family and other social supports –Type and quality of specific rehabilitation training program
Aggressive rehabilitation that includes regular cardiovascular exercise beyond the first few months following a stroke can increase aerobic fitness and reduce the risk of a second stroke(33)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Occupational therapy Speech/swallowing therapy Psychology/psychiatry Social services V ocational therapy Ophthalmologist/neuro-ophthalmologist Recreational therapy Physiatry Support groups/community-based  exercise programs Nutritionist Smoking cessation
other considerations: Authors of a meta-analysis  of 14 RCTs (N = 736 participants) published in 2017 found that a combination of aerobic and strength training resulted in improvements in cognitive function in chronic stroke survivors(4)

Results of a randomized trial conducted in Canada suggest that an exercise and recreation program can significantly benefit executive functioning in community-dwelling  chronic stroke survivors with mild cognitive impairment(20) –Twenty-eight  stroke survivors were randomized to one of 2 intervention groups: one group received a 6-month  structured program that included 2 sessions of exercise training and 1 session of recreation per week, and the other group received the same intervention 6 months later –Compared with the delayed intervention group, in the first 6 months the intervention group significantly improved selective attention, working memory, and functional capacity
treatment summary: Authors of a Cochrane systematic review updated in 2016 found that cardiorespiratory training reduced disability after stroke, and there was enough evidence to advise incorporating this training to improve the speed and tolerance of walking. They found too few studies to assess the effects of resistance training(3)

Researchers who conducted a study in Egypt found that cycling exercise improved gait parameters in stroke survivors(5) –40 male patients (age range 45–60  years) post ischemic stroke were included in the study; patients were divided into control group (GI) and study group (GII)  –Both groups performed task-oriented  progressive resistive exercises for lower limb muscles 3 times per week for 10 weeks.The GII group also performed 30 minutes of cycling at each exercise session –Results showed significant improvements in gait speed, step cycle, and step length of the affected side in the study group compared to the control group
Researchers in China found that participation in early post stroke rehabilitation enhances cardiovascular fitness and improves functional outcomes(6)

Aerobic exercise induces a cascade of events that leads to increased brain-derived  neurotrophic factor (BDNF), a key facilitator of neuroplasticity involved in motor learning and rehabilitation after stroke.The authors of an article published in 2018 investigated the efficacy of high-intensity  interval training (HIIT) as an alternative exercise intervention post stroke. Preliminary research (N = 10 studies) demonstrates that HIIT is associated with improvements in functional, cardiovascular, and neuroplastic outcomes(7)

Authors of a meta-analysis  published in 2020 found that even during the chronic stage of stroke, exercise training (aerobic and resistive) results in significant improvements in gait and balance asymmetry (8)

Researchers who conducted an RCT in Brazil found that aerobic cycling significantly improved subjects’ lower limb muscle strength, mobility, and functional capacity post-acute  stroke(9) –20 subjects were enrolled in the study and were equally divided into control group (CG) and intervention group (IG) –Subjects in CG performed conventional physical therapy twice a day for 5 consecutive days; subjects in IG performed one conventional physical therapy and one cycle ergometer session once daily for 5 days –Outcome measures included 10MWT, BBS, and ICUMobilityScale

In an RCT, researchers in Sweden found that intensive aerobic exercise twice weekly early in subacute mild stroke improved aerobic capacity, walking, balance, health-related  QOL, and patient-reported recovery(26) –Fifty-eight  patients who had a mild stroke and were discharged to independent living were enrolled a median of 20 days post–stroke  onset –Participants in the intervention group did 60 minutes of group aerobic exercises including 2 sets of 8 minutes of exercises with intensity up to exertion level 14 or 15 (out of 20) on the Borg RPE scale. Exercises were conducted twice weekly for 12 weeks. The nonintervention group did no organized rehabilitation or exercises –Significant improvements were obtained in the intervention group in peak work rate, maximum walking speed, and TUG test scores. Aerobic exercise was also associated with the following patient-reported  improvements: improved QOL scores and improved perceived recovery on the Stroke Impact Scale (SIS) –Only the patient-reported  improvements were measured at 6-month  follow-up.  The patient-reported  improvements persisted at 6months

Authors of a 2020 systematic review of 30 RCTs (N = 1051 subjects) found that resistive training improved muscular force, motor function of lower and upper limbs, health-  related QOL, independence, and reintegration compared to other interventions(10)

Authors of a 2018 systematic review found that progressive resistance training has a large effect on strength compared with no intervention or placebo, but that this large increase in strength does not seem to carry over to improvements in activity. Eleven studies involving 370 participants poststroke were analyzed(37)

Authors of a 2018 systematic review found that resistance training protocols after stroke varied widely and did not necessarily adhere to the American College of Sports Medicine guidelines for resistance training. The authors recommend that strength-training  protocols in future trials adhere more closely to the guidelines in order for their effectiveness in stroke to be more accurately determined(38)

Researchers in the United States who conducted an RCT found that eccentric resistance training was superior to concentric resistance training, more effectively improving bilateral neuromuscular activation, strength, and walking speed after stroke(11) –Thirty-four  adults poststroke participated; neuromuscular activation was assessed using isokinetic dynamometer and surface EMG

In an RCT, researchers in Sweden found that eccentric overload flywheel resistance aided in regaining muscle mass and function and functional performance in individuals poststroke(27) –Thirty-two  individuals with chronic stroke participated. Eccentric flywheel exercise of the lower extremity was performed twice weekly for 12 weeks by the intervention group; the control group maintained daily routines

Researchers in South Korea found that a progressive resistance training program can improve the stride of the affected side of patients after stroke and improve walking speed(21) –Fifteen chronic stroke patients participated; outcomes measured included peak torque of knee extensors and gait ability measured by electric gait analysis of walking speed, walking cycle, affected-side  stance phase, and affected-side stride length

Researchers in the United States who conducted an RCT with crossover design found greater functional gains with the addition of power training to functional task practice and no deleterious consequences (e.g., exacerbation of spasticity or musculoskeletal complaints)(12) –Nineteen chronic stroke patients participated. Power training consisted of high-intensity,  dynamic resistance training; outcome measures used were Wolf Motor Function Test, FMA, Ashworth Scale, and FIM

Researchers in the United States found that lower limb muscle power training resulted in improvements in muscle strength and power that were accompanied by improvements in self-selected  and fastest comfortable walking speeds(22) –Twelve patients, 6–60  months poststroke, participated in 3 training sessions per week for 8 weeks. Exercises included leg presses, calf raises, and jump training, all performed at high concentric velocity, as well as fast walking

Researchers in Canada investigating barriers to delivering high-intensity  training identified therapists’ beliefs about the intervention, which may not be congruent with the evidence, as a key factor. System-level  factors such as resources and access to graded exercise test and monitoring equipment were also identified as barriers(39) –The authors emphasized that ways to facilitate higher-intensity  interventions in clinical practice need to be identified

Researchers in South Korea found significant differences in the muscle activity of the paretic lower limb between fast and slow exercises(23) –Ten stroke patients performed fast and slow squat exercises. Rectus femoris was found to be highly activated during the fast squat exercises but not during the slow squat exercises. The authors concluded that training programs for stroke patients need to be designed with consideration of the speed of the exercises

Authors of a 2016 systematic review with meta-analysis  concluded that respiratory muscle training is an effective method of improving respiratory function, respiratory muscle strength, and exercise tolerance in patients poststroke. Studies included were RCTs that examined the effects of respiratory muscle training versus nonrespiratory muscle training in patients poststroke. Eight studies met inclusion criteria(28) –The authors recommend assessing respiratory muscle strength before commencing a poststroke rehabilitation program to identify patients for whom respiratory muscle training might enhance functional abilities –More well-designed  RCTs are needed to determine the best methods, including device, frequency, intensity, and duration, to meet the needs of individual patients or patient subgroups

Researchers in South Korea found that abdominal muscle strengthening accompanied by inspiratory muscle training improves pulmonary function poststroke and may be used as an adjunct to conventional physical therapy(29) –Based on an RCT involving 23 patients with stroke –The effects of abdominal muscle training and inspiratory muscle training on pulmonary function, balance ability, and abdominal muscle thickness were measured –Forced vital capacity, FEV1, deep abdominal muscle thickness, and Berg Balance Scale scores were significantly improved in the experimental group compared to the control group

Researchers in China who conducted an RCT found that rehabilitation training of core muscles can effectively improve balance, function and walking speed of patients post stroke(13) –180 individuals with chronic unilateral hemiparetic stroke participated –Participants were divided into observation and control group (N = 90), both of which received conventional stroke rehabilitation 5 days per week for 8 weeks. The observation group (OG) also received core muscle stability training –Outcome measures used included BBS, 10MWT, Brunnstrom staging, Fugl-Meyer  motor assessment(FMA), and ultrasound measurements of abdominal wall thickness of the paralytic side (transverse abdominis, internal and external obliques) –Results showed significant improvements in all outcome measures, including increased thickness of the transverse abdominis in the OG

Authors of a Cochrane systematic review published in 2017 found moderate evidence that circuit class rehabilitation (therapy that involves working in groups rather than individually with a therapist) is an effective way to improve mobility after stroke and that patients may be able to walk farther, faster, and with more confidence in their balance. Seventeen  studies that involved 1,299 participants were included. Positive effects were obtained by persons whose stroke was more than a year prior as well as those whose stroke was within the past year(14)

Authors of a 2016 systematic review and meta-analysis  found that balance can be improved by an exercise therapy program in the chronic phase after stroke. Subgroup analyses were performed for the different types of exercise training (balance and/or weight-shifting training, gait training, multisensory training, high-intensity aerobic exercise training, and other training programs) to identify which regimens were most effective. There was a significant improvement after balance and/ or weight-shifting  training and after gait training, but no significant effects were found for other training regimens(40)

A systematic review of RCTs (N = 1,772 participants) published in 2018 showed that inclusion of treadmill training in conventional physical therapy post stroke results in significant improvements in walking speed and ability. Authors state that further research is needed to identify optimal training parameters (16)

Researchers in South Korea found in an RCT that mat-based  Pilates may be beneficial for improving gait in poststroke patients and the intervention could be applied to individuals with various levels of disability by adjusting the intensity of training(30) –Twenty individuals with unilateral chronic hemiparetic stroke participated –The Pilates exercise program was conducted by certified Pilates instructors and consisted of 3 sessions per week for 60 minutes, for 8 weeks. Exercises focused on core muscle stability –Outcome measures included 3-D motion analysis of gait. Results showed that an 8-week  Pilates program effectively improved patients’ gait parameters . improved motor control: Improved balance–BBS–ABC Scale–Falls Efficacy Scale–Functional reach test
Improved locomotion or ability to ambulate–Community walking test–Preferred gait speed (10MWT)–DGI
prevention of secondary complications: Improved quality of life–SF-36–Stroke Impact Scale–NIHSS

maintenance or prevention: Encourage patient compliance with medications that can reduce stroke risk
Encourage patient compliance with lifestyle changes that can reduce stroke risk (e.g., weight loss, smoking cessation, stress reduction)
Educate patients and the public on signs and symptoms of a stroke, as early medical intervention can limit disability

Participation in aerobic training must be sustained indefinitely to prevent return to the initial deconditioned state; therefore, a maintenance program should be followed after termination of formal training sessions(41)
Continuously monitor patients with safety issues (e.g., imbalance, poor judgment, memory impairment)
Prevent injury of hemiplegic upper extremity by not using it to transfer or mobilize the patient and by monitoring its position when the patient is lying down or seated
Prevent contractures with proper positioning, stretching/ROM, and splints if indicated
patient education: See patient information from the American Stroke Association website at https://www.stroke.org/
